title: For Sale:  EM Polycoated Pistol Bullets 9mm, .40, .45, .380
postcontent:
Get the advantages of a full metal jacket for the price of hard cast lead. Eggleston Munitions Polycoated Bullets feature a tough polymer coating which allows reloaders to push bullets faster with no leading of the bore and less smoke. The polymer creates a strong bond with the surface of each bullet so that it will not chip, peel, or crack even under extreme conditions.  

These bullets are available in several popular pistol calibers including: 
9mm / .380ACP (.356-.358") 
.40/10mm (.401-.402")
.45 (.451-.452")

We are constantly adding new bullet styles and weights to suit our shooter's needs, and are even developing bullets for use in high velocity rifle cartridges.

Visit our website to see more information and place an order:
http://www.egglestonmunitions.com/bullets.html

Also feel free to contact us via E-mail to arrange an order or face-to-face transaction. Eggleston Munitions is located in Colorado Springs, CO.

*Note: We sell only projectiles for hand loading and re-loading, we do not sell fully loaded ammunition. 

Price list per 1000 bullets:
.380 98 gr.             $70
9mm 124 gr. :         $83
.40/10mm 180 gr. : $115
.45 200 gr. :           $128
.45 230 gr. :           $140

Shipping is $11 for a thousand (we can fit anywhere from 2 to 3 thousand per box, depending on caliber and grain), and orders of 2000 bullets or more ship for $5. Buy in bulk and save!

title: For Trade:  .204 Ruger Varminter NEW-In-Box
postcontent:
New-In-Box...UNFIRED!
This will be a perfect Varminter for someone.
I bought this May 26th, 2013.
Paid $470 for it.
Got it home, tested the trigger pull and found it would not reduce to the 3.5 pound as advertized.
Called T/C (which is now a division of Smith & Wesson)...talked to a tech. He sent me a return label and I shiipped the rifle to them.FREE...
Receved the rifle back in one week and they had replaced the trigger. It now breaks at 3.5 pounds! Nice...plus...Great Service from them!

I then bought a 8.50-20x50mm Mueller Eradicator Scope...$239 +tax.and Rings, $23.

The scope has been mounted for my eye relief, but NOT bore sighted...so you will need to adjust for your shooting style.

I got this to take Prairie Dog Hunting but plans fell thru and I am looking to sell or trade this...with or without scope.
For those 'scope bashers' who only like or use Nightforce, Schmidt & Bende or Swarovski scopes...well good for you :) I have had 4 of these Muellers on my rifles from 17HMR up to 300 Win Mags and I LOVE these things...
NEVER had any failures....just saying!

Below is from T/C :
Thompson/Center introduces the T/C Venture, the most value packed bolt action rifle available on the market today. 
Thompson/Center Venture offers a 5R rifled match grade barrel and match grade crown, adjustable precision trigger and a classic style composite stock that puts it in a class all its own. 
A rugged, reliable tool for the outdoorsman, the T/C Venture features T/C's renowned innovation, craftsmanship and cutting edge barrel technology. Guaranteed to deliver Minute of angle accuracy... 1 inch groups at 100 yards!. 
Specifications and features:
Thompson/Center Venture bolt action rifle
.204 Ruger caliber
3+1 capacity magazine
5R rifled match grade barrel
1:10 twist
Match grade target crown
Externally adjustable trigger from 3.5 to 5 pounds
Two position safety
Classic Sporter composite stock with traction panels
Nitride fat bolt design
60 degree bolt lift
Made in the USA
41.75" overall length
13.5" length of pull

This is a NEW rifle and scope.
I have ~$700 in it....so Trades based on this.
Cash offers need to be reasonable.....and those offers will be responded to.
Idiotic offers will be treated with the respect they deserve.
I am retired and trade for fun and to try different guns...so let's keep it fun for all.
++++ The ammo, dies and new cases can be negotiated, since I have NOT included their cost in what I have in the rifle and scope+++++
The Redding Cometition Seating Die was $110.00 alone, at GRAF, Brass was $40.00 at Cabelas, and Redding Body Die was $30 at Midway and the Lee Collet Dies were also $30.00 and Ammo was $44.00 for two boxes..So to replace these...at least $250.00+++++
Trades I would look at...?...most anything except no blackpowder.
I really like, BUT NOT limited to:
.45 acp handguns...but also .357 wheel guns in Carry size, not a 9mm fan Unless it is 
something like Sig Nightrmare....you get the idea. 
+++ Can Ship thu FFL if out of MN!+++

title: For Sale:  Trijicon Accupoint TR-24G W/ Bobro Mount Green Triangle  TR24G
postcontent:
For sale is a lightly used (it may as well be new for practical purposes) Accupoint TR-24G. There's absolutely nothing wrong with it, I'm just going back to ACOGs. Honestly I got this thing a year ago and never even sighted it in.

TR-24G: 1-4x24, also the reticle pic doesn't do it justice. When outside the triangle is crazy bright, but you can dial it down if need be (the fiber optic has a sliding cover). Uses fiber optic and tritium to achieve a battery free illuminated reticle in all conditions. Very nice/sharp optic favored by a lot of 3 gun shooters.

It sits in a Bobro extended QD mount. I've tried pretty much every quick-release mount (Larue, ADM, GG&G), and consider Bobro to be heads and tails above them. No adjustments, just returns to zero every time with the clamping of one lever.

Really looking for cash on this one, will negotiate a little, so if a trade is a must I am open minded, but please make it advantageous to me a little (after all, cash pays bills, not guns (however nice they may be)). Have a great day!

title: For Sale:  MAC Modele 1950 9mm Luger Military Collectible Rare Vietnam Trophy
location: Blaine, Whatcom County, Washington, United States
postcontent: Summary Description-> Type: Single Action; Chamber: 9x19mm Luger/Parabellum; Weight unloaded: app. 860 g / 30.3 oz; Length: 192 mm; Barrel length: 112 mm / 4.40 inches; Capacity: 9 rounds. This gun was brought back from Vietnam by a friends relative many years ago and just found recently stored away. I have broken it down (easy) to photograph and check parts. It is in found condition and needs to be cleaned. The serial number is a rare C series. Supposedly there are less than one thousand of these guns in the USA, and chromed ones like this one are much rarer. The general cosmetic condition seems to be excellent. Just a few minor pits in the chrome and a slight barely noticeable chrome separation right at the end of the barrel. All the parts seem to be here. Includes one original magazine in stainless. I think that one spring may be very dirty or a bit weak - the really small one for the trigger - because the trigger only fires if a slight amount of pressure is put up on the mechanism. The hammer spring seems to be strong and excellent. Maybe just a cleaning and lube will do the trick, but I am not even close to being knowledgeable on repairs. No signs of rust or major defects. Barrel looks good. Grips are not damaged, and screws are good. I have done a lot of macro photos and have tried to describe this to the best of my ability. So, please ask questions if you need more info - Due to the age and type of gun, I am selling this as-is, unfired, with no guarantees. Do not fire this unless you have had it checked out first by an expert who deems it safe. Make sure you qualify to purchase this gun. I will only ship it to an FFL who will take it directly from me, or, if it needs to go FFL to FFL, there will be an additional $25 cost. Description from website 'World Guns - Modern Firearms': At the end of World War Two, the French army had a mixed stock of pistols. The Police were armed with an even wider array of various pocket pistols made by French companies, as well as some foreign pistols, mostly imported from Belgium and made by FN. Recognizing the need for a more modern and powerful military pistol (which would fire NATO-standard 9x19 ammunition also suitable for sub-machine guns), in late 1946 the French army issued a requirement for a new 9mm military pistol. Several designs were tested and in 1950 the army adopted a design from the state-owned MAS arsenal based in St.Etienne (Manufacture d'Armes de Saint-Etienne). This pistol, known as the Mle.1950 or M1950 was broadly based on the pre-war M1935 pistol, strengthened to use the more powerful 9x19 ammunition which also was intended for MAT-49 sub-machine guns. These pistols were made by two state-owned armories, MAS and MAC (Manufacture d'Armes de Chatellerault) between 1956 and 1978. During their lifetime, many pistols were factory refurbished and returned for service. In general, the troops liked these guns for their strength and durability; accuracy was less than ideal, but still acceptable for a military pistol. The M1950 pistol was manufactured by the MAC (Chatellerault) factory between 1956 and 1963, and by the MAS (St.Etienne) factory between 1961 and 1978. The Model 1950 pistol (also designated as Mle.1950 or M1950) is short-recoil operated, locked-breech weapon of all-steel construction. It uses Browning-type locking with the barrel engaging the slide via two lugs made on the top of the barrel, just ahead of the chamber. Unlocking and locking is controlled by the swinging link, which connects the barrel to the frame. The trigger is single-action, with an exposed hammer and a manual safety mounted on the slide. The hammer / sear module is made as a single, easily removable unit, following the 1935-vintage Charles Petter patents. Magazines are of single stack variety, and the pistol is fitted with an automatic magazine safety; the sights are fixed. Manual safety is lever at the left side of the slide, next to the hammer. To put on safety, push the lever up; to set to “Fire”, pull the lever down How to disassemble M1950 pistol: 1) remove the magazine by pressing the magazine release button; 2) check that the chamber is empty; 3) pull the slide slightly back and hold it there; 4) while holding the slide slightly retracted, push in the slide stop pin from the right, then pull the slide stop out of the frame to the left; 5) release the slide carefully and then push it forward and out of the frame; 6) put the slide upside down, and remove the return spring with its guide; 7) remove the barrel from the slide; 8) pull the hammer unit up and out of the frame. Reassemble in reverse order. Subject to prior sale as it is also  listed on gun broker and other websites. Shipping will be between $25-$45, depending on wether your FFL will accept from a private seller. If it needs to go FFL to FFL, the cost will be $45. More pictures can be sent to serious buyers.

title: For Sale/Trade:  Marlin Model 9 - Camp 9 - Camp Carbine - 9 MM
postcontent:
The Marlin Camp Carbine is a self-loading carbine chambered for either 9mm Parabellum or .45 ACP, formerly manufactured by Marlin Firearms Company of North Haven, Connecticut. The carbine was manufactured from 1985 to 1999.

As the name implies, it was designed as a utility firearm to be used around hunting camps for foraging or defense. It was made in 9mm Parabellum and .45 ACP calibers and can use the same magazines as popular handguns in those calibers, in keeping with a convenient American tradition of having a carbine and handgun using common ammunition. The carbine operates by direct blowback. Usually, the receiver is drilled and tapped for a scope mount. The stock was made of walnut-finished Maine birch.

The Camp Carbine uses a detachable magazine that inserts into the magazine well in front of the trigger guard. The Camp 9 rifle magazine can be replaced by magazines from 59-series S&W pistols. The Camp 9 magazine well is sized for 12-round magazines; magazines with higher capacities extend beyond the bottom of the well. A 20-round magazine was produced, but discontinued in 1989. Numerous aftermarket magazines and drums were produced for both models.

This Model 9, SN 10885230 is in like new condition with the original factory inspection sticker still attached. The metal and wood are flawless and the bore is bright and crisp.
From what I can find via the Serial Number I believe this Model 9 was manufactured in 1990.

The original recoil spring was replaced with a stronger one and new aftermarket recoil buffer is installed.

Included in the sale are; A Barska Red Dot Sight, Leather Sling, 1 Marlin 12 rd factory magazine, 3 aftermarket 20 rd  magazines and 1 aftermarket 30 rd magazine for a total of 5 magazines. I have fired rounds from all the mags with no problems.

This is a fun to shoot Carbine in like new condition.

Asking $850.00 OBO

postcontent:
KNAPP SPORT SAW
Knapp Sport Saw made by the Pioneer Co. in Boise Idaho patent no. 206,369. This saw has a course set of teeth on one side for cutting branches etc. and the other side has finer teeth for cutting bones when butchering etc. Total length including handle is 13 inches long. The handle has a compartment with screw cap for keeping your matches in. 

VERNCO KNIFE
It's a heavy-made knife and measures 10 1/2" total length. The blade is 5 3/4" inches long. Marked Hand-Honed, Vernco HI-CV Stainless Japan on one side of the blade. Knife is one piece from tip through the hardwood handle. The hardwood handle has a reinforcing steel bar on one side and on the other side it shows the 3 pins. Grip has a real good feel and has thumb grip indentation on top.

LEATHER SHEATH
The leather sheath is well used and has some thread missing on seams. It has had the name Murray etched in it and someone has tried to shave the name off. Belt slots on back of sheath are almost tore through. Sheath is still useable at this time but, may need replaced or repaired in the future.

This is a nice set up for a hunter. or anyone else that has a need for a knife and saw.

Arsenal, Inc., the premier American importer and manufacturer of semi-auto rifles, is proud to offer to American shooters the Bulgarian-made SAM7R. This 7.62x39 caliber rifle combines authentic, high-quality features rarely seen in the American market. From its intermediate-length trapdoor buttstock to its removable four-port muzzle brake, every component of the SAM7R is engineered to provide decades of dependable and accurate service. Arsenal’s Exclusive Milled And Forged Receiver Each SAM7R receiver is milled from a hot-die hammer forged receiver blank by the Arsenal Co. of Bulgaria. Other milled-receiver AKs are machined from bar stock, but Arsenal’s hot-die hammer forging produces stronger and finer-grained steel. Internal voids and cooling deformations are eliminated by the 5-ton hammer forging process. Each forged receiver blank requires over 5.5 hours of milling before assembly. postcontent:
YOU WILL BE BASICALLY GETTING 2 GUNS (will come with original barrel and funiture so can switch back in forth in about 5 min from a home defense gun to hunting rig) .. It has had exactly 15 rounds fired. ASKING $550 OBO/TRADE

The Rem 870 when using the pisol grip style stocks is a much better design than the Moss 500 because the Rem 870 has a CROSS BOLT safety that you can engage without moving your hands away from the trigger assembly. The Moss 500"s or like style shotguns that have the SAFETY on the reciever and when set up with pistol grips make you move you hand away from the ready fire position to engage the safety switch on top of reciever. So for a Home "D" style pistol grip shotgun the Rem 870 is a wise choose. Remember seconds count in a emergency. Enough with my rant and about this gun...
